markdownRemark.html:
Joel Simon

Entry from 2021-12-12 23:48

I met Joel today — it was cool. They had a human brain in a vat, over their fireplace. A real brain... that was once a real person. He didn't seem surprised by it at all, and when I asked how it got there, he answered, "well, we have a neuroscience professor in the house."

Joel's story is that he was working full-time, and he released Artbreeder as a side project. I remember what it looked like in the beginning, circa 2018. It generated a lot of strange, abnormal-looking creatures that weren't particularly aesthetic.

But now the art has become good— fantastical, imaginative. The project grew and went viral on TikTok. Someone on Youtube made a video about artbreeder that got 3 million views (this happened a couple months ago). So Artbreeder is now profitable enough to be his full-time thing.

It took a while. Artbreeder got started in 2018, and it really needed the GANs to get better before it started taking off 3 years later.

Molly Mielke

We hung out over dinner at Burma Love. She's headed to Argentina with Devon Zuegel and a bunch of other Twitter friends for the holidays.

  • I'm kind of glad that those people are doing that, because it's a snapshot of what older friendships are like
  • (Laura is in South Africa with a bunch of her friends for the holidays)
    • in the future our friend group will have a higher net worth and we can go to Argentina

Quitting Figma

  • she loved Figma the first time she was there for an internship, but when she came back for full-time she hated it
    • in less than a year the team grew a ton and no longer feels like a startup
    • Figma is now an enterprise product. Doing design for an enterprise product is not creative, mostly involves responding to feature requests from sales teams
    • On the day she started full-time, she knew she wanted to quit (similar to Mackenzie)
    • she loved her manager when she was an intern, they would do stuff together, but now she has a manager who is more hands-off

Moth Minds

  • Moth Minds is a platform for donors
    • she has an initial cohort of 10 different donors, people like Patrick Collison who are well-known in different fields
    • Andy and Taylor are donating as a group
      • Taylor has always wanted to make a design studio (for people like Azlen and Matt), I'm glad that he's finally taking steps forward
    • the value of a grant is more than money; she believes the brand and credibility of the donor is extremely important
      • she's acting mostly like a consultant; she's making a home page for each donor
    • The idea of Moth Minds came to her two years ago, and seems extremely obvious
      • she started talking to people about it and taking it more seriously around a month ago

      • A lot of people want to start grants. The idea of Moth Minds is easy, I just have to execute on it.

Contracting

Contracting is a great way to have a community. Molly is working on Moth Minds alone, so she took preemptive steps to make sure she doesn't go crazy. She is doing two part-time jobs: a writing role at Stripe Press with Tamara Winter and one other person, under Patrick Collison, and a design role at Primer making a blogging platform for the kids. She's doing one day on each contracting role every week, and spending the rest of her time on Moth Minds.

  • I thought this was really interesting
  • My mental model of work is that you should only be doing one thing, ever. Perhaps there's another statement, equally axiomatic: you have to be with people. If the second is not satisfied, then maybe you should trade off on the first?
    • there was a time at Google X when I was also doing a side project that took most of my time from 6 pm to 3 am, then I would show up to work and be pretty low-energy for the daytime. I thought that this was evidence that you shouldn't do multiple things at once, but perhaps there's something about doing a job that provides a lower-amplitude but consistent form of feedback that you don't get from independent projects
  • I asked if she would have trouble context-switching, but basically she said it's worth it.
    • It's also about knowing yourself. She has experimented with different modes of work before
    • She also thinks that the people you work with in contracting can also help you with your own thing. I believe this, esp since the contracting roles seem high-quality
  • The contracting roles are in a team (of contractors). She's working directly with 2 other people at Stripe and 1 other person at Primer.
    • I think pair-programming or the equivalent should be the default mode of working. There's this implicit assumption that people should be treated like separate processors in wait of a task, but I think it's the thing in between people that gets stuff done
      • See Sah and Sawhney, Larry and Sergey

Mackenzie

Mackenzie is awesome! We hung out for a couple hours on the night before my flight.

  • Laura told her she could be a good VC, she has a good sense of people
    • I think so too. She perceives and verbalizes things about people that I usually only sense subconsciously:
      • she said Max is autistic, observed that at Science's own party Max was just wandering around, staring at people without saying a word
      • she says that Steve gives her Cambridge vibes, he has eclectic interests that he takes seriously for the sake of it
      • she wants to like Molly but feels she's full of too many Twitter aphorisms
    • She says Laura tries to fit her into a category of people, and currently it's the "zen buddhist" category
  • She met Milan recently and really likes him
  • She says Laura never prepares for meetings, she just goes into them and does well
    • probably from a lot of practice
  • I told her that we were possibly speaking with competitors, and she said that Laura is speaking with a competitor tomorrow
    • about what? she doesn't even know — Laura isn't even preparing for the meeting!
  • She said her interview with Laura went horribly
    • I said I suspect that our real-time evaluations of our conversations are often wrong (thinking about my meetings in Boston, I usually felt horrible during them but then people would extend an invitation at the end to hang out more)
    • she said maybe just the bar is really low
  • A lot of leverage that Laura has comes from being in the original batch of Thiel fellows
    • all of their investors are people she met when she was 16 and have built relationships with

    • These people literally watched her grow up

  • She can't take Loyal seriously
    • longevity for dogs is funny
  • I told her she was my only female friend and we laughed about it, she also only has one other female friend

Recruiting

  • It's a loop that you can learn quickly; she told me I should do it once so that I have it under my belt
  • She spent 3 hours a day on work this week (LOL)
    • Laura has to speak with the high-profile people directly, so Laura often has to do most of the writing

Mackenzie just wants to work on consciousness. How does one work on consciousness? She's just hoping to be in a place that gets her closer to what it is.

She speaks with high precision. In conversation she alters your mode of thinking, flips a switch in your brain so that you seek greater precision yourself.
